dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Chris Hemsworth wearing a five-pound inflatable suit for a baker role in The Avengers is just wild to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Chris Hemsworth wearing a five-pound inflatable suit for a baker role in The Avengers is just wild to me.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And he still ended up on the list of Hollywood's worst-paid actors, losing over 76 million dollars last year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And he still ended up on the list of Hollywood's worst-paid actors, losing over seventy six million dollars last year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's not just him though—Dwayne Johnson, the so-called "Tooth Fairy," topped that list with nearly 90 million in losses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not just him though-Dwayne Johnson, the so-called Tooth Fairy, topped that list with nearly ninety million in losses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dwayne Johnson, also known as the Rock, tops the Forbes list of the worlds ten highest-paid actors, collecting $89.4 million between June 1, 2018, and June 1, 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and his pay structure is just bizarre—like, 2.35 million upfront for Jumanji, plus a tiny percentage of the deficit? That's rough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and his pay structure is just bizarre-like, two point three five million upfront for Jumanji, plus a tiny percentage of the deficit? That's rough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hell collect an upfront salary of up to $23.5 millionhis highest quote yetfor the forthcoming Jumanji: The Next Level. He also commands up to 15% of the pool from high-grossing franchise movies, including Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle, which had a worldwide box office of $962.1 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And he's only making $700 per episode for that HBO golf show? That feels… intentionally low, almost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he's only making seven hundred dollars per episode for that H B O golf show? That feels... intentionally low, almost.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And he is paid $700,000 per episode for HBOs Ballers and seven figures in royalties for his line of clothing, shoes and headphones with Under Armour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like these huge franchise films are actually putting actors deeper in debt, even when the box office numbers look massive on paper.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like these huge franchise films are actually putting actors deeper in debt, even when the box office numbers look massive on paper.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That gross was so big that it secured spots on this years top-earner list for Chris Hemsworth, Bradley Cooper and Paul Rudd, in addition to Downey; together, they earned $284 million, with most of that coming from the franchise.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Robert Downey Jr. supposedly lost around 5.5 million from Avengers: Endgame alone, which made almost 28 billion worldwide. How does that even happen?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Robert Downey Jr. supposedly lost around five point five million from Avengers: Endgame alone, which made almost twenty eight billion worldwide. How does that even happen?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Robert Downey Jr. gets $20 million upfront and nearly 8% of the pool for his role as Iron Man, and that amounted to about $55 million for his work in Avengers: Endgame, which grossed $2.796 billion at the box office.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I think it's all about how the deals are structured—like, they get a cut of the deficit, not the profit. So if a movie's budget is insane, they owe money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think it's all about how the deals are structured-like, they get a cut of the deficit, not the profit. So if a movie's budget is insane, they owe money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the lucrative twenty-twenty deal ($20 million upfront and 20% of gross profit) doled out to the likes of Harrison Ford and Tom Cruise may be more or less gone, Hollywood still has its big-money brands, those actors who can promise an audience so big that they command not only an eight-figure salary to show up on set but also a decent chunk of a films nebulous poolor the money left over after some but not all of the bills are paid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Bradley Cooper's situation is especially brutal—he put so much of his own money into A Star Is Born, and it ended up costing him 400 million in debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Bradley Cooper's situation is especially brutal-he put so much of his own money into A Star Is Born, and it ended up costing him four hundred million in debt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It paid offthe movie, which had a production budget of only $36 million, grossed $435 million worldwide, leaving Cooper with an estimated $40 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, passion projects can really backfire. Even with Lady Gaga attached, it just didn't recoup.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, passion projects can really backfire. Even with Lady Gaga attached, it just didn't recoup.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It paid offthe movie, which had a production budget of only $36 million, grossed $435 million worldwide, leaving Cooper with an estimated $40 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's crazy to think that these A-listers are basically betting against themselves with these contracts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's crazy to think that these A-listers are basically betting against themselves with these contracts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And according to that entertainment lawyer, studios have all the leverage now—actors like Scarlett Johansson can't even negotiate fair deals anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And according to that entertainment lawyer, studios have all the leverage now-actors like Scarlett Johansson can't even negotiate fair deals anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Celebrities such as Downey and (Scarlett) Johansson currently have extreme leverage to demand enormous compensation packages from studios investing hundreds of millions of dollars in making tent-pole films, such as The Avengers series, entertainment lawyer David Chidekel of Early Sullivan Wright Gizer & McRae told Forbes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, after seeing that Forbes list, I'm starting to think nobody in Hollywood actually knows how to make money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, after seeing that Forbes list, I'm starting to think nobody in Hollywood actually knows how to make money.

artist_script:
HostA: Chris Hemsworth wearing a five-pound inflatable suit for a baker role in The Avengers is just wild to me.
HostB: Right? And he still ended up on the list of Hollywood's worst-paid actors, losing over 76 million dollars last year.
HostA: It’s not just him though—Dwayne Johnson, the so-called "Tooth Fairy," topped that list with nearly 90 million in losses.
HostB: Yeah, and his pay structure is just bizarre—like, 2.35 million upfront for Jumanji, plus a tiny percentage of the deficit? That’s rough.
HostA: And he’s only making $700 per episode for that HBO golf show? That feels… intentionally low, almost.
HostB: It’s like these huge franchise films are actually putting actors deeper in debt, even when the box office numbers look massive on paper.
HostA: Robert Downey Jr. supposedly lost around 5.5 million from Avengers: Endgame alone, which made almost 28 billion worldwide. How does that even happen?
HostB: I think it’s all about how the deals are structured—like, they get a cut of the deficit, not the profit. So if a movie’s budget is insane, they owe money.
HostA: And Bradley Cooper’s situation is especially brutal—he put so much of his own money into A Star Is Born, and it ended up costing him 400 million in debt.
HostB: Yeah, passion projects can really backfire. Even with Lady Gaga attached, it just didn’t recoup.
HostA: It’s crazy to think that these A-listers are basically betting against themselves with these contracts.
HostB: And according to that entertainment lawyer, studios have all the leverage now—actors like Scarlett Johansson can’t even negotiate fair deals anymore.
HostA: Honestly, after seeing that Forbes list, I’m starting to think nobody in Hollywood actually knows how to make money.
